awd_abstract_narration:
The Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation supports the research program of Professor Mahdi Abu-Omar of the University of California, Santa Barbara.  This project is focused on the area of sustainability or "Green Chemistry".  The project seeks new ways to produce industrially important chemicals and fuels.  This work is relevant to the economy of United States, the largest producer of chemical products globally. Chemical producers seek renewable starting materials.  They also seek to use abundant resources when possible.  Safety in a chemical process is a third consideration. These goals motivate research on chemical reactions that are environmentally friendly. Professor Abu-Omar's project uses cheap and abundant elements such as manganese and iron along with plant-based groups to form the new catalysts that in turn, speed up the desired reactions.  Detailed analyses of the rates of these chemical reactions give insights into how the catalyst works on an atomic level. In support of the broader impacts of the project, Dr. Abu-Omar is actively engaged in an outreach program involving community college (CC) students, who are largely from underrepresented groups, in laboratory research. 

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Mahdi Abu-Omar of the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) is designing and synthesizing catalysts based on first row transition metals, specifically manganese and iron.  These catalysts are further designed using lignin-based ligands (LBL). The synthesis of LBL is high yielding, atom economical, and satisfies many of the Principles of Green Chemistry. The design of LBL provides a motif that is highly suited for coordination chemistry but yet resistant to oxidative degradation. Iron- and manganese-LBL complexes are then employed to generate chlorine dioxide on-demand from chlorite in aqueous solution under ambient temperature and at neutral pH. A significant improvement in chlorine dioxide production is to avoid oxygen atom transfer (OAT) from the catalyst to chlorite to make chlorate, which is a persistent pollutant. Under investigation is the oxidation of phenanthrene and phenols (aromatic compounds) by in situ generated chlorine dioxide. In a unique approach, two catalytic cycles are coupled in tandem to achieve oxidations with dioxygen as the stoichiometric oxidant.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Chemical manufacturing in the U.S. is growing. However, to ensure continued sustainable growth, the chemical enterprise must conduct efficient syntheses and separations, avoid hazardous materials, and invent catalysts to unlock sustainable and environmentally benign pathways. In this research program we prepared earth-abundant iron and manganese compounds the utilize bio-based ligands to stabilize these metals. We discovered that these compounds catalyze the formation of chlorine dioxide, a potent disinfectant used in treating produced water from fracking. Our preparation of chlorine dioxide is achieved in water at neutral pH, under ambient temperature and avoids the production of waste co-products. The research delineated the rates of reaction, the mechanism by which iron and manganese operate and the pathways that lead to the catalyst degradation.

Employing tandem catalysis, we prepared green solvents from cellulose/biomass. These solvents are highly polar and can be employed in demanding reactions in the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries. These solvents are environmentally friendly and less polluting with reduced health hazards.

The use of first row transition metals in catalysis is an important component to advancing sustainable chemistry. These elements such as iron and manganese are cheap, abundant, and nontoxic. Combining Earth-abundant elements with bio-derived ligands that stabilize the metal and enhance its function is interesting because it mimics nature and is compatible with the environment. We have been able to make iron and manganese catalysts that are compatible with water and enable reactions in water under ambient conditions, avoiding the need for volatile and harmful organic chemicals.

Two talented graduate researchers and one undergraduate student were trained in chemical synthesis, catalysis, kinetics, and sustainable chemistry. As a result of this project, these graduate students were prepared for academic and industrial research careers. The undergraduate student was admitted into a graduate program and is pursuing research in catalysis engineering.

 


 



Last Modified: 09/20/2023
Modified by: Mahdi M Abu-Omar
